Dear Susan Joy Mitchell:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
4/17/2023-4/25/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12205 Required Staff
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient
number of competent staff to carry out the provisions
covered by these rules. The workload for each staff
member shall not be more than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services
worker for purposes of providing direct services in foster
care, independent living, adoption, or post adoption
services or a combination thereof.
8 of 8 foster care caseload carrying staff are over caseload compliance
requirements.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
4 of 14 open youth case files reviewed contained updated service plans that were
completed outside of the required timeframes by 3, 3, 5 and 41 days, respectively.
This represented 4 of 47 updated service plans reviewed

(6) Service plans shall be signed by the social services

CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service
worker and the youth in independent living at least once
each month at a youth’s place of residence.
1 of 6 open files of youth living independently contained documentation that the
worker did not go into the youth's home for 2 consecutive months.
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum

(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is

F OM 722-06B F AMILY TEAM MEETING
3

FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement or
no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business
days of the FTM.
8 of 14 total open youth files reviewed did not have all required FTM documentation.
10 required FTMs were not documented to have been held and 5 documented
FTMs did not have any paperwork uploaded.

CONTACT WITH CHILD'S CAREGIVERS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face
contact in the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If
there is more than one caregiver, such as a primary and
4

secondary caregiver, the caseworker must have a face-
to-face contact with the secondary caregiver in the home
at least once each quarter.
1 of 8 open files of youth in foster care placements did not have documentation that
the second caregiver was present for home visits at least quarterly.
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
S IGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the
Case Service Plan and the Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to
review, and I will have the opportunity to express
my disagreement with the Case Service Plan and
Parent Agency Treatment Plan when the
information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify,
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the
electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.

FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child/youth's placement date to the following
• Foster care provider.
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a
temporary court ward.
- Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
- At reunification. Subsequent medical passports
are not required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
- At or prior to each placement.
- Quarterly.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
5 of 14 open youth files reviewed did not contain all required signatures on medical
passports. This represents initial placement and quarterly updates.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• No technical assistance was required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• One Special Evaluation Report that had not yet been approved contained
confidential information. A reminder to remove all of that information prior to
approval was provided.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There was 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The one SER related to corporal punishment was reviewed and found to be
completed thoroughly and accurately.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows.
The first was submitted in response to renewal inspection report dated 4/22/2022
for which the corrective action plan was approved on 5/4/2022. Fifteen violations
were addressesed in that corrective action plan of which the agency has achieved
and maintained compliance in 11 areas. The remaining 4 were repeated during
the current inspection. Additionally, 2 of the 4 were repeated during the last two
inspections and will require additional corrective action planning. All four of the
non-repeated violations established in this report were isolated incidents that did
not span across the full selection of reviewed files.
The second was submitted in response to special investigation report
2022C0212018 dated 7/13/2022 for which a CAP was approved on 8/8/2022.
Compliance with that CAP was demonstrated during a six-month monitoring
period. The one violation established in that investigation, R 400.12206(1) has not
since been repeated.
The third was submitted in response to special investigation report 2022C0112021
dated 10/6/2022 for which the corrective action plan was approved on 11/16/2022.
Compliance with that CAP is currently being monitored for a six month period,
ending on 5/16/2023. Of the three violations established in that report, R
400.12421(C) & FOM 722-06J have not since been repeated. The third, FOM 722-
7

06, was repeated during this inspection and will be addressed through a corrective
action plan.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment was reviewed and discussed during the
entrance meeting. The chief administrator accurately identified areas of non-
compliance which were largely attributed to staffing turnover and difficulty hiring
qualified/experienced staff resulting in errors due to learning rule & policy
requirements.
Financial Overview
No financial concerns were identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
None of the staff members interviewed reported any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency appears to have adequate space and equipment to perform required
job functions. Files are stored securely in a file room that prevents unauthorized
access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
